Re: “A Wet Winter Won’t Save California”
Researchers Diffenbaugh and Field adeptly articulate the long-term threats of global heating (sorry, but accelerating global climate disruption we’re already enduring has rendered the term “global warming” obsolete). But the “two lessons” they cite from these disasters leave out the ultimate lesson: Humanity must end its dependency on fossil fuels for energy as quickly as possible.
Their solutions focus only on water: Rights, markets, storage, regulations, infrastructure and more. They don’t even mention the resource we’re burning at the rate of 25 million years of photosynthesis per year—and increasing—in the process fatally poisoning our planet. Fossil fuels are what most need regulation, to phase them out. We can do everything Diffenbaugh and Field recommend regarding water, and we’ll be rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic.

Wrong argument. The science you represent does not work. The wet/dry cycles you identify are, as you say, not caused by global warming. They are normal. You cite past periods of heavy rainfall and the inability of aquifers and storage basins to hold the excess. Build more storage capacity and humans can help nature. Revel in the rainfall and give in to our sloth and we will suffer as in our current droughts. Ignore the relationship between populations, agriculture and water supply as we now do and welcome to California. These are not climate issues, they are public policy and human nature problems. Yes there is global warming but it is not the club that will solve California's drought. Try the harder problem: US.

Carbon doesn't move the jet stream.  California's drought is largely the result of geoengineering.  At the very least, such activities must be filtered from other observable weather, or else the data is simply contaminated.  In short, the public, but even the scientific community, generally has a very poor understanding of the depth and extent of sophisticated government and commercial geoengineering experiments and their effects on local meteorology.

I'm no water scientist but I do know what a dam is and why they build them. If you've got water you can't capture on flowing rivers, dams solve the problem. Lots of California's water comes from flowing rivers, particularly from the Sierras. Dam them up and you capture a lot of water you otherwise would lose. That requires a balance between environmental concerns and water needs. I sure would think that the water authorities in California would be looking into this right now.

It would seem to be logical to do a better job of water storage in California and many other places. This is just common sense.  Yes, there have been big droughts before in California. Maybe this one will prove to be worse than some of the other big ones. The big difference is that there are so many more people in California than there were during many of the earlier droughts. I have insurance on my house. If the owner goes out in the winter, I have a back up heat source. It is the same with water, get a back up plan in place, you may need it.

You entire miss the point, fatally so. Lengthy (100+ year) droughts are normal for California's cycles. But in those previous years, the available fresh water was not used for 40 million residents and agribusiness that provides produce for millions more. Californians, mostly through agriculture, are using vastly more water than ever before, draining aquifers that may never replenish.

Those are the facts, and your terms about stampeding scientists (buffalos, all of them!,) a feckless media (definitely liberals, I'd say by measuring their fecklessness,) scientists who defend out of greed, a conflating political confreres ... those bear baiting terms have absolutely no weight.

As a native Southern Californian, I've seen the likes of overdevelopment for the past 50 years, and jrj90620 is right: Politicians will continue to encourage growth to "stimulate the economy."

Right now, in San Diego, our local City Council members are allowing yet another growth spurt, this time called "infill." Our city hardly has a vacant lot anywhere, so to "encourage the use of public transportation," members will let builders uproot more neighborhoods by constructing yet more apartments near trolley tracks.

The trolley is too expensive for most people to use, and users will be left to fend for themselves to get to their final destinations after leaving the trolleys.

The bus system is as poor now as it was 50 years ago when I used to have to wait 1 1/2 hours for a transfer to get home from work.

We need to learn to "infill" by sharing households, forgoing spacious houses so each child can have his or her own bedroom and homeowners can show off how well off they are -- until they're foreclosed upon.

Much of Southern California, not just San Diego, lives in concrete jungles created over desert land -- and the weather about which we all bragged is becoming more like the East Coast, with heat and humidity, and floods.

I don't understand jrj's remarks about "you can never have enough welfare recipients." What does this have to do with growth?

Californians need to grow up, not out, and find new methods of living and conserving. I don't believe they will.
While Democrats feel the Bern, the conservative punditariat taste the ashes.

it seems to me despite the headline, this article has an overly rosy conclusion. We are trending to no snowpack in the winter in Calif and this represents 30% of future water storage during spring melt off. So right there we are down 30%, we are rapidly draining the subsurface water that is left. Yes conservation can help a bit, but exactly where are we going to make the difference up year after year? Desalinaton simply wont work THe one being built in Carlsbad is costing over 1 billion and will provide 18% of water needed in san diego county. Do for san diego we need to build at least 6 more and then we need to build hundreds and hundreds more all over the state. They use an incredible amt of energy and do environmental damage, so we are just escalating our ecological problems and speeding up the global warming process even more. No, we cant  build a  water pipeline from the great lakes to Calif nor from Canada to Calif..........not feasible nor would either probably agree to giving their water over........I cant imagine the thousands and thousands of upscale people in LA and SF doing the sacrifice needed to conserve water in the extreme month after month, year after year. The inevitability to me seems a very sparsely populated Calif of the future and total havoc being wreaked on the  rest of the US financially and in other ways as a result. The  thing I notice from bloggers  on this subject is a highly developed denial of reality.
